title: How to Classify Polynomials: By Type or Degree

steps.title: Identify the number of terms.
steps.content: Identify the number of terms. A term consists of a coefficient, variable, or both. For example, you could have 4 {\displaystyle 4} , x 2 {\displaystyle x^{2}} , or 4 x 2 {\displaystyle 4x^{2}} . You can use the number of terms to determine the type of polynomial you’re dealing with. Monomials have 1 term. Binomials have 2 terms. Trinomials have 3 terms. Polynomials with more than 3 terms are usually just identified by their degree. The variables should have non-negative integer exponents.

steps.title: Check out these examples.
steps.content: Check out these examples. 2 x {\displaystyle 2x} is a monomial. 7 {\displaystyle 7} is also a monomial, since it can be written as 7 x 0 {\displaystyle 7x^{0}} 3 x + 1 {\displaystyle 3x+1} is a binomial. x 5 + 2 x 2 + x {\displaystyle x^{5}+2x^{2}+x} is a trinomial.

steps.title: Identify the degree.
steps.content: Identify the degree. The degree of a polynomial is the largest exponent present in a term. The standard form is when a polynomial’s terms are arranged in descending order of exponent size. For factoring info, check out our guide on factoring a cubic polynomial .

steps.title: See these examples from the last method:
steps.content: See these examples from the last method: 2 x {\displaystyle 2x} is a 1st degree polynomial. 7 {\displaystyle 7} is a zeroth degree polynomial, since it can be written as 7 x 0 {\displaystyle 7x^{0}} . 3 x + 1 {\displaystyle 3x+1} is a 1st degree polynomial. x 5 + 2 x 2 + x {\displaystyle x^{5}+2x^{2}+x} is a 5th degree polynomial.
